I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan for the COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure 
Support (CARES) Program under the Countercyclical Support Facility COVID-19 pandemic 
response option (CPRO).1 
 
2.  Afghanistan is classified as a fragile and conflict-affected situations (FCAS) country. The 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic has adversely impacted Afghanistan’s economy and 
its population. To mitigate these impacts, the government has adopted emergency pro-poor 
countercyclical measures and expenditures to strengthen the health system, expand social 
protection, and support macroeconomic stabilization and job creation. The proposed program will 
support the government’s COVID-19 countercyclical pandemic response and financing needs to 
help mitigate the adverse health, social, and economic impacts of the crisis, while targeting poor 
and vulnerable groups and ensuring gender mainstreaming.2  
 
3.  Afghanistan meets all the criteria required to access the CPRO under the Countercyclical 
Support Facility (Table 1 and Appendix 4). The program is fully aligned with the operational 
priorities in Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s Strategy 2030 (with a differentiated approach for 
FCAS) related to (i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, (ii) accelerating 
progress in gender equality, (iii) promoting rural development and food security, (iv) strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity, and (v) fostering regional cooperation and integration.3

A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
4.  Health-related challenges. Since the first COVID-19 case was reported on 23 February 
2020, based on World Health Organization (WHO) data the number of confirmed cases reached 
44,706 with 1,687 deaths as of 23 November 2020. The government’s capacity constraints in the 
health sector and limited infrastructure have affected the developmental and health-related 
services.4 An ongoing armed conflict and political uncertainties, including about the intra-Afghan 
peace negotiations during 2020, have further complicated the fragile health situation.5  
 
4  Afghanistan ranks 170th out of 180 economies in the human development index (overall 0.496, 0.360 for women and 
0.583 for men) in 2019. Only 32% of the population have access to grid-connected electricity and 43% use improved 
sanitation facilities. United Nations Development Programme. 2019. Afghanistan Human Development Indicators.  
5  A peace deal was signed between the United States and the Taliban in February 2020. The political impasse over 
the presidential elections concluded with two leading candidates making an agreement in May 2020. Prospects for

5.  Afghanistan is a landlocked country with a population of 38.9 million. It borders Iran, the 
People’s Republic of China, Pakistan, as well as Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Turkmenistan in the 
Central Asia region, which are vital for regional trade and employment. The influx of 671,759 
returning Afghan migrants and refugees from Iran and Pakistan during January−October 2020 
has accelerated the spread of the virus because of the limited border surveillance, testing, and 
quarantine capacity.6 According to the United Nations Office for Coordination of Humanitarian 
Affairs, about 400,000 people were internally displaced as a result of the conflict or disasters from 
natural hazards in 2019, with an additional 86,419 people displaced by the end of May 2020. 
These factors have complicated the provision of health and social services during the pandemic.  
 
6.  A health emergency of such magnitude has aggravated the pressures on the country’s 
public-sector-led health care system, providing mainly basic health care (with limited private 
health care providers), due to large deficiencies in hospital beds, medical personnel, equipment, 
and testing capacity.7 Hospitals also faced challenges to provide health services in areas of active 
conflict. The health care expenditures are primarily borne by high out-of-pocket expenditures of 
the households (73%) because of lack of health insurance, while the rest is covered by the 
government  (6%)  and  international  donors  (21%). 8  With  inadequate  personal  protective 
equipment, as of October 2020, 10% of the COVID-19 infections were among health care 
professionals, and their subsequent deaths are undermining the response capacity.9 Afghanistan 
ranks 161st out of 195 economies in its capacity to rapidly respond to and mitigate the spread of 
the epidemic, with a score of 23.6 out of 100 based on the Global Health Security Index in 2019.10 
Because there is no national death register, COVID-19 cases and deaths are underreported.11 
Under the scenario of easing community restrictions, daily infections (including those not tested) 
could reach 36,840 by 1 March 2021 with 2,808 deaths, requiring 10,797 hospital beds (2,002 
intensive care unit beds) compared to 5,286 beds (440 intensive care unit beds) available.12

uncertainties and economic shocks triggered by natural hazards, Afghanistan has maintained a 
sound  record  of  macroeconomic  management  leading  up  to  the  crisis. 13 The  structural

8.  Economic  impact  of  the  pandemic.  The  government  tightened  the  containment 
measures by placing Kabul and other urban centers under lockdown from late March until early 
August 2020. While the pre-shock macroeconomic management has been sound, the pandemic 
has had a substantial negative economic impact because of the business closures, disruptions in 
supply chains, downturn in trade and remittances, and drop in consumer demand. Based on IMF 
estimates, the economy is projected to contract by 5.0% in 2020 with a downturn in industry and 
services, in contrast to the pre-COVID-19 GDP growth projection of 3.5% for 2020. In 2021, the 
GDP growth is projected to rebound to 4.0%.15 Under a more pessimistic scenario based on World 
Bank estimates,16 incorporating the risks related to the second wave of infection, weather-related 
shocks, security challenges, political uncertainty, and potential decline in international grants, 
GDP contraction could range between 5.5% and 7.4% in 2020 with only 1.0% GDP growth in 
2021. ADB estimates GDP contraction of 5% in 2020 and 1.5% GDP growth in 2021.17

$2.31 billion (12.1% of GDP) in 2020 compared to $2.66 billion (14.1% of GDP) in 2019 and the 
pre-COVID-19 2020 projection of $2.71 billion (13.0% of GDP). Expenditures are projected to 
increase to $6.35 billion (33.3% of GDP) in 2020 driven by COVID-19 and pro-poor-related 
spending, compared to $5.28 billion (28.0% of GDP) in 2019 and the pre-COVID-19 2020 
projection of $5.56 billion (26.6% of GDP). The budget deficit excluding grants and budget support 
loans is projected to increase to $4.04 billion (21.2% of GDP) in 2020, compared to $2.62 billion 
(13.9% of GDP) in 2019 and the pre-COVID-19 2020 projection of $2.85 billion (13.6% of GDP).18

almost all border points with neighboring countries were closed with limited incoming shipments. 
By the end of June 2020, most border points were reopened.19 Because of disruptions to land

contract by 35.4% and imports by 2.4% in 2020. The current account deficit–GDP ratio is 
projected to increase from 27.0% in 2019 to 30.6% in 2020. The current account including official 
transfers as a share of GDP is projected to have a smaller surplus of 9.3% in 2020 compared to 
11.7% in 2019. The official reserves will increase to $8.9 billion in 2020 (compared to $8.6 billion 
in 2019), equivalent to 14.3 months of import coverage. The afghani–dollar exchange rate has

11.  Inflation. Given Afghanistan’s dependence on imported food and nonfood products, 
consumer price inflation surged during the pandemic. The IMF figures indicate that inflation 
increased from 2.3% in 2019 to 5.4% in 2020 and is forecast to remain high at 4.8% in 2021. The 
food price inflation spiked in the first half of 2020 following imposition of border control and 
lockdown measures in urban centers. The food price inflation is forecast to reach 17.5% by the 
end of 2020 (with its period-average rate projected at 13.3% for the full year).20 Price volatility has 
moderated  since  April  2020,  following  distribution  of  wheat  from  strategic  grain  reserves, 
enforcement of anti-price-gouging regulations, and the border reopening for food imports.  
 
12.  Banking  sector.  Financial  soundness  and  profitability  of  the  banking  sector  have 
deteriorated during the pandemic.21 Driven by withdrawal of savings and working capital by firms 
to meet business costs in the face of revenue declines, total banking sector deposits declined by 
3% in the first quarter of 2020. Annual growth in net credit to the private sector is projected to 
drop from 1.8% in 2019 to 1.0% in 2020 because of the economic downturn and increasing risk 
aversion by banks in response to declining debt servicing and repayment capacity of businesses. 
As of June 2020, while the ratio of capital to risk-weighted assets stood at 26.7% (higher than the 
thresholds of 8.0% under Basel II and 10.5% under Basel III), the ratio of nonperforming loans to 
gross loans increased to 29.4% compared from 14.5% at the end of 2019.  
 
13.  Micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises and unemployment. Nearly 250,000 
registered micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) have been hit hard by the 
pandemic.22 An impact assessment during May–June 2020 showed that lockdowns and fall in 
consumer demand have placed pressures on MSMEs because of supply chain disruptions, input 
shortages, loss of labor, forced sale of assets, limited working capital, cash flow shortages, 
revenue losses, and lack of access to credit.23 Because of urban lockdowns, travel to retail stores 
and workplaces dropped by 50%. Financial inclusion is very weak, with only 15% of the adult 
population having a bank account and only 5% of MSMEs having access to a line of bank credit, 
with most of the financing handled through hawalas (a money transfer arrangement in the informal 
sector) (footnote 9). MSMEs accounted for nearly 1.6 million jobs in services and industry, and 
MSMEs with less than 10 employees accounted for more than 80% of nonagricultural employment 
before the pandemic. The unemployment rate (including the informal sector) is projected to 
increase from 23.9% in 2019 to 37.9% by the end of 2020. 24 If underemployment is added, the 
figure will reach 53.5% of the labor force, corresponding to nearly 4.8 million people being either 
unemployed or underemployed in 2020 (an increase of 1.5 million people from previous year). 
 
14.  Remittances. Economic downturn in countries with large Afghan diasporas (e.g., Iran and

15.  Poverty. The World Bank estimates that because of COVID-19, the national poverty rate 
could increase to at least 61.0% (and potentially to 72.0%) from 54.5% in 2017, 25 forcing an 
additional 1.9 million–6.0 million people into poverty by the end of 2020 (footnote 16). Lockdown 
measures, supply disruptions, and reduced crop sales have impacted the agriculture sector, 
accounting  for  44%  of the  workforce  and  60%  of  household  incomes.  The  pandemic  has 
deteriorated the livelihoods of urban households, especially for daily wage earners in the informal 
sector. Day labor from activities like shopkeeping, street or market sales, construction, or personal 
services accounts for more than 40% of non-agricultural employment for the bottom quintile, 
corresponding to 2 million households (15 million Afghans). Up to 80% of employment is in the 
informal sector, with no social and legal protection for workers. Spikes in prices of staple foods 
due to shortages or disruptions in food supply have adversely affected households in the bottom 
60%, for whom food purchases comprise half of their total consumption. About 12.4 million 
Afghans could be pushed into food insecurity, disproportionately affecting women and children.26  
  
16.  Impact on women and the vulnerable population. The pandemic has exacerbated the 
gender-based inequalities27 as a result of (i) increased restrictions on women’s participation in 
social and economic life because of the nationwide lockdown in addition to restrictions from the 
traditional and patriarchal norms; (ii) limited access to gender-sensitive health care services, with 
only 15% of nurses and 2% of medical doctors being female, and social norms prohibiting female 
patients  from  being  treated  by  male  doctors;  (iii)  inadequate  dissemination  of  COVID-19 
information  because  of  lower  female  literacy  (18%)  compared  to  male  literacy  (62%);  (iv) 
increasing economic dependence and risk of food insecurity as women have limited labor force 
participation (29% for working-age women in 2016) 28 and old-age pension coverage29 as well as 
higher job losses compared to men, with more than 50% of employed women in MSMEs not able 
to come to work during the pandemic; (v) vulnerability to gender-based violence; and (vi) poor 
access  to  sanitation.30 Ongoing  conflict  causing  casualties,  lockdown  measures,  and  the 
pressures on the health system have aggravated the hardship faced by the families of the military 
and civilians killed during conflicts, and disabled veterans and civilians with special needs. 
Internally  displaced  families,  returning  migrants  and  refugees  face  difficulties  in  finding 
employment and paying for basic food and housing, which have increased their debt. The 
pandemic has affected 9 million school-age children, of which 39% are girls. Around 20% of 
women and 41% of children under 5 years of age are malnourished as of 2019 and this will likely 
increase, underscoring the importance of food distribution for humanitarian assistance.

18.  Health-related measures. The government responded to the COVID-19 emergency by 
introducing a nationwide lockdown in late March 2020 followed by preventive social distancing 
and containment measures such as requirement for masks; closures of schools, businesses, and 
public places; release of prisoners; and restrictions on public transportation until early August 
2020. Border crossings and flights resumed in mid-July 2020. Schools and universities reopened 
in phases since 22 August 2020. Provincial emergency committees were formed in April 2020, 
comprising local administrators, civil society, and development partners in 34 provinces. The 
preventive measures have been implemented under the authority of the provincial governments. 
The National Emergency Response Plan (NERP) for COVID-19 was approved by the Ministry of 
Public Health (MOPH) in March 2020 and a new structure within the MOPH was created to 
implement the NERP and the national action plan. The MOPH has been strengthening the 
readiness and capacity of the medical facilities, including emergency procurement of medical

supplies and equipment. These measures also have a gender focus with the establishment of 
women-only  treatment  facilities  in  hospitals  and  provision  of  appropriately  sized  personal 
protective gear for female health workers.31 Fourteen COVID-19 testing labs were established 
across the country with five in Kabul. Including the tests by the private hospitals, a capacity of 
5,500 tests per day has been reached. As of 19 November 2020, 133,691 tests were conducted, 
which is only 30% of the estimated need. In addition to the 525 MOPH sites, surveillance sites in 
airports, borders, and city entrances have been set up and mobile teams trained. The MOPH has 
recruited and trained more than 6,000 medical staff with 3,000 new staff planned to be hired. 
Medical staff have been provided with salaries and incentive payments. A gender-sensitive public 
awareness campaign has been carried out by the MOPH and Ministry of Women Affairs in all 
provinces, distributing more than 10 million pieces of COVID-19-related information, and a call 
center was set up at the MOPH. Given low female literacy, the Ministry of Women Affairs visited 
women in hospitals, jails, shelters, businesses, orphanages, and banks across 26 provinces to 
raise awareness and share gender-sensitive information. The street children were also supported 
with sanitary kits. The medium- and long-term public health and preventive measures include the 
strategy for national health security agenda for all hazards and pandemic preparedness under 
the NERP, and capacity building of the MOPH with support from development partners. 
 
19.  Social protection measures. The government has undertaken several measures to 
mitigate the risks of food insecurity and rising poverty, and expand the coverage of social safety 
nets, targeting women and vulnerable people. The MOF provided an emergency cash transfer of 
$31.43 million to all provinces through the Independent Directorate of Local Governance given 
the essential role of local governments in implementing containment measures and providing

been targeted as households headed by women for these in-kind and financial relief measures.

women and 30,943 are female heirs. Out of 130,311 pensioners and female heirs (inclusive of

Identification Document (E-NID). A one-time cash transfer of AF6,000 per person was provided

civilian disabled people, and families of those killed during conflicts.

and its adverse social and economic impacts reduced. The program has three outputs: (i) COVID-

jeopardizing fiscal sustainability; (ii) targeting social protection; (iii) establishing mechanisms for 
expenditure tracking and independent verification; and (iv) providing TA when country systems 
are weak. The program incorporates lessons from the budget support loans of other development 
partners in Afghanistan, such as (i) leveraging community-based institutions for targeting social 
assistance and (ii) focusing on economic recovery through multisector support.

contraction in industry by 5% and in services by 9.6% in 2020.

$5.28 billion (28.0% of GDP) in 2019 and the pre-COVID-19 2020 projection of $5.56 billion (26.6% of GDP).

informal sector with no social and legal protection for the workers. Spikes in import prices due to shortages or 
disruptions in food supply have adversely affected households in the bottom 60%, for whom food purchase comprises 
half of their total consumption. About 12.4 million Afghans face the risk of being pushed into food security deprivation. 
 
Impact on women and the vulnerable population. Afghanistan ranked 143rd out of 162 economies on the Gender 
Inequality Index in 2018 (compared to 154th out of 159 countries in 2016). The pandemic exacerbated the gender-
based inequalities because of (i) increased restrictions on women’s participation in social and economic life due to 
nationwide lockdown in addition to restrictions from the traditional and patriarchal norms; (ii) limited access to gender-
sensitive health care services, with only 15% of nurses and 2% of medical doctors being female, and social norms 
prohibiting female patients from being treated by male doctors; (iii) inadequate dissemination of COVID-19 information

  due to lower female literacy (18%) compared to male literacy (62%); (iv) increasing economic dependence and risk of 
food insecurity as women have limited labor force participation (29% for working age women in 2016) and old-age 
pension coverage as well as higher job losses compared to men with over 50% of the employed women in MSMEs 
not able to come to work during the pandemic; (v) vulnerability to gender-based violence; and (vi) poor access to 
sanitation. About 70% of the employed women (both formal and informal) are in the agricultural sector while 24% are 
in manufacturing. The share of women in wage employment in non-agricultural sector is only 10% as of 2018. Pension 
spending is 0.6% of GDP covering only 9.2% of population over 64 years of age and 8% of the labor force. Ongoing 
conflict causing casualties, lockdown measures, and the pressures on the health care system have aggravated the 
hardship faced by the families of the military and civilian people killed during conflicts, and disabled civilians and 
veterans with special needs. The pandemic has affected 9 million school-age children, of which 39% are girls. Around 
20% of women and 41% of children under 5 years of age are malnourished as of 2019 and this will likely increase, 
underscoring the importance of food distribution for humanitarian assistance. 
 
2. Countercyclical  On 16 March 2020, the Government of Afghanistan established the High-level Committee for COVID-19 as an inter-
Development  ministerial task force, chaired by the president and the first vice president and rolled out its comprehensive pro-poor 
Expenditures  countercyclical pandemic response package with gender focus. The High-level Committee has comprised MOF, 
MOPH, Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development, IDLG, National Statistics and Information Authority, Ministry 
of Commerce and Industry, and Kabul Municipality. The MOF was tasked with the coordination of the development 
partner support while MOPH with the implementation of the health sector support.  
 
Under the instructions of the committee, MOF made two amendments to the 2020 national budget —on 7 April 2020, 
approved by Presidential Decree No. 82, and on 29 July 2020, approved by Presidential Decree No. 47—and a 
revision during the midyear review on 28 September 2020, approved by the cabinet, to reprioritize resources for 
responding to the economic downturn, and undertaking the countercyclical pandemic response package. The 
pandemic response package amounts to $633.92 million (3.3% of GDP), comprising health-related measures ($70.35 
million), social protection measures ($169.71 million) and macroeconomic stabilization measures ($393.86 million).  
 
Health-related measures. Aligned with NERP, the MOPH has undertaken (i) strengthening of the capacity of medical 
facilities, testing laboratories and surveillance sites, including at border crossings; (ii) emergency procurement of the 
necessary medicines and medical equipment such as testing kits, ventilators, medical masks; (iii) recruitment, training 
and incentive payments of the medical staff, and (iv) gender-sensitive public awareness campaign (details on health 
sector related expenditures provided under Criteria 4).  
 
Social protection measures. The government has undertaken countercyclical measures to expand the social 
protection to mitigate the risks of food insecurity and rising poverty. Coverage of the social safety nets has been 
expanded to include women and vulnerable people such as children, old-age pensioners and their female heirs, IDPs 
and refugees, military and civilian disabled people and the families of the killed people during conflicts, who have been 
disproportionally impacted by the adverse impacts of the pandemic. The MOF provided an emergency cash transfer 
of AF2.42 billion ($31.43 million) to all 34 provinces through IDLG given the essential role of the local governments in

implementation of containment measures and provision of vital services and social support to communities. The total 
IDLG budget was raised by $45.3 million since the beginning of 2020 to augment pandemic response capacity.  
 
To address food shortages and stabilize the food prices, the government opened the national food reserves for public 
use in April. A bread distribution program, supervised by the first vice-president, was launched in all provinces in May 
2020 and implemented by the local governments and municipalities. The program benefited more than 310,000 
families below the poverty line. District and village-level monitoring committees have been formed to identify and 
document the people in need and supervise the bread distribution process through local bakeries. Packages with 4.5 
kilograms of wheat were distributed to 1,000 families in Kabul during the business closures. In coordination with the 
COVID-19 Emergency Committee and the Kabul mayor’s office, the government covered the water and electricity bills 
of 350,000 poor families, who had a bill equal to or less than AF1,000 ($13) for 2 months during the lockdown in April–
May 2020, providing relief to 1.5 million residents (50% of utility users) in Kabul. About 10% of the total households 
have been targeted as households headed by women for these in-kind and financial relief measures. The government 
has supported the coverage of 99,368 old-age pensioners, of which 5,468 are women and 30,943 female heirs. Out 
of the total 130,311 pensioners and their female heirs (inclusive of 9,379 new beneficiaries in 2020), 86,404 have 
biometric registration under E-NID, which will improve targeting of these beneficiaries. The Ministry of Refugees and 
Repatriation provides one-time cash transfer benefitting 41,500 IDPs and refugees from Iran and Pakistan. At the 
beginning of 2020, remuneration was provided to 338,056 people, comprising both military and civilian disabled people 
and the families (including female heirs) of people killed during conflicts. Out of the total, 272,006 were civilians. During 
2020, the remuneration coverage has been increased by 32,570 additional military and civilian disabled people, and 
families of those killed during conflicts 
 
Macroeconomic  stabilization  measures.  The  government  has  rolled  out  countercyclical  macroeconomic 
stabilization measures to strengthen the monetary policy, provide fiscal relief, strengthen support for a critical SOE, 
the MSMEs and affected sectors, and promote pro-poor and gender-inclusive job creation. Although the government 
has not introduced any large tax waivers or deferrals, it has extended filing deadlines for the first and second quarters 
of the fiscal year by 45 days for individuals and business taxpayers to ease tax compliance. The government also 
provided financial support to the power utility company, Da Afghanistan Breshna Sherkat to cover the losses from 
lower electricity demand and past due electricity bills of the government agencies which were pending for the last few 
years. This is aligned with the reforms supported by the World Bank and ADB to improve the operational efficiency 
and financial sustainability of the power sector. To create nearly 1.9 million temporary jobs and 60,000 permanent 
jobs, the Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation and Livestock has supported processing and packaging units and cold 
storage at the rural community level under the government’s Afghanistan Crop Management Project to prevent 
wastage of high value perishable fresh fruit and vegetables that could not be exported. Agriculture sector is critical for 
women’s livelihoods as 70% of female employment mainly takes place in this sector.  
 
On 1 October 2020, the High Economic Council of Afghanistan approved a 2-year MSME support package for $294.8 
million, with $200 million to be provided in 2021 and the remainder in 2022. It provides (i) $44.80 million for exemptions 
or deferments of tax penalties, municipality fees, property rent for government land and buildings, (ii) $120 million for

  first loss fund to cover banks’ losses from MSME lending, (iii) $50 million subsidized loans, (iv) $50 million for support 
for industrial parks, (v) $10 million for vocational training and (vi) $20 million support for access to international 
markets. The support will also help streamline existing MSME-related programs at Ministry of Industry and Commerce 
and Ministry of Women’s Affairs, including the program for Women Rural Development and Women Economic 
Empowerment. Exemptions and deferments of tax penalties, municipal fees and rental expenses on government 
property have been partially introduced in 2020 and will continue to provide fiscal relief to MSMEs during the 
implementation as well. The support includes a first-loss fund, managed by the MOF and DAB including support from 
the ACGF, to cover banking sector losses from MSME lending as well as subsidized loans to MSMEs provided by 
state-owned and private sector banks in Afghanistan.  
 
In 2020, there are 7 private commercial banks, one private Islamic bank, 3 state-owned banks, and 2 foreign bank 
branches in Afghanistan. There is also a formal microfinance sector, consisting Microfinance Investment Support 
Facility for Afghanistan and 6 microfinance institutions.  
 
Small-scale MSMEs in the manufacturing sector will be supported in industrial parks in five major cities (Kabul, 
Kandahar, Nangarhar, Mazar, and Herat). Local universities will support incubators for entrepreneurs. The vocational 
training will be provided in collaboration with the Technical and Vocational Education and Training Directorate, Ministry 
of Higher Education, Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs and nongovernmental organizations. Trade-related support 
aims at strengthening access of the MSMEs to international markets and increasing integration of Afghanistan’s 
chambers of commerce and entrepreneurs with regional partners. 
 
On the monetary side, the DAB has reduced the provisioning requirements for loans that are covered by risk 
guarantees from the ACGF to sustain lending to the private sector. With this policy, bank credit to MSMEs with ACGF 
guarantees as a share of total bank lending is projected to be at least 17% by end 2021. To strengthen the banking 
sector, DAB has been regularly monitoring early signs of stress and stands ready to provide liquidity to the financial 
sector as needed. The frequency of Financial Stability Committee meetings has been increased. The DAB developed 
a post-COVID-19 improvement plan for the banking sector from July 2020 until December 2021. The DAB has (i) 
enforced the prudential requirements but at the same time suspended the administrative penalties and fees with no 
retrospective applications for breaches or noncompliance as a form of regulatory forbearance until July 2020; (ii) 
postponed the implementation of international financial reporting standards (IFRS-9) to June 2021; and (iii) frozen 
loan classifications at the end of February 2020 as a pre-pandemic cutoff date. 
 
3. Pre-shock Record of  Despite the difficult security situation, elevated political uncertainties and external shocks triggered by natural hazards 
Generally Sound  that hampered economic activity, Afghanistan has maintained a generally sound pre-shock record of macroeconomic 
Macroeconomic  management  leading  up to the crisis. Afghanistan’s macroeconomic and financial  management policies were 
Management  anchored under the IMF’s 3.5-year ECF arrangement, approved in July 2016, and completed in December 2019. The 
ECF was a critical driver of structural macroeconomic, fiscal and governance reforms, strengthening (i) tax system 
with value added tax, (ii) monetary policy for price and exchange rate stability, (iii) fiscal governance, (iv) anti-

corruption, (v) state-owned banks, (vi) management of public investment, fiscal risks and spending efficiency, (vii) 
asset declaration, and (viii) social protection.  
 
Afghanistan achieved GDP growth of 2.6% in 2017, 1.2% in 2018 and 3.9% in 2019 driven by the agriculture sector’s 
recovery. The DAB has lowered the inflation from 5.0% in 2017 to 0.6% in 2018 and 2.3% in 2019. It has also taken 
measures to improve the capital adequacy, governance, and liquidity of the banking sector, and strengthened the 
financial supervisory framework by establishing the Financial Stability Committee. To strengthen the financial inclusion 
and financial sector intermediation, the government has started implementation of the National Financial Inclusion 
Strategy, 2019–2024 since September 2019.  
 
With continued aid inflows (reaching nearly 40% of GDP), the government has maintained a broadly balanced fiscal 
stance with budget deficit (including grants and loans)−GDP ratios of 0.7% in 2017 and 1.1% in 2019 while having a 
surplus of 1.6% in 2018. Reflecting improvements in budget execution and prioritization, operating expenditures−GDP 
ratio has declined from 19.7% of GDP in 2017 to 18.5% in 2019, while the development expenditures−GDP ratio has 
increased from 8.0% in 2017 to 9.5% in 2019 and pro-poor spending−GDP ratio has increased from 3.0% in 2017 to 
3.7%  in 2019. Reflecting prudent fiscal  and debt  management, international reserves (over  $8 billion during 
2017−2019) have accounted for 14.5 months of imports in 2019 and public debt−GDP ratio has remained stable at 
about 6% under a policy of highly concessional external borrowing. Domestic borrowing is negligible in Afghanistan 
with only two promissory note issuances worth 1.2% of GDP in 2017 and 0.5% of GDP in 2018 but the issuances 
were discontinued in 2019 and 2020.  
 
Large current account deficits have continued to be financed by donor grants. The current account surplus including 
official transfers has increased from 7.6% in 2017 to 12.2% in 2018 and 11.7% in 2019. To reduce aid dependence, 
the government has adopted measures to promote exports and regional trade. Tax reforms have been initiated in 
2019 for expansion of tax base, adoption of value-added tax, planned by early 2022 and increased tax collection 
efficiency by consolidating large taxpayers (accounting for 16% of domestic revenues including customs) under Single 
Large Taxpayer Office. These reforms have improved the revenue−GDP ratio from 13.1% in 2017 to 14.1% in 2019.  
 
The macroeconomic management during the pandemic has been on track and further supported by the IMF’s ECF, 
approved in November 2020. The government remains committed to implementation of macroeconomic structural 
reforms and PFM reforms to improve the effectiveness of the countercyclical pandemic response measures. 
 
4. Structural Reforms  The government has promptly responded to the COVID-19 pandemic by introducing strict nationwide containment 
(Health Sector  measures to prevent the community transmission and strengthening the capacity and readiness of the health system 
Response)   for the pandemic and future health emergencies over the medium and long term. The government’s health sector 
structural reforms have been pro-poor with strong gender focus. 
 
Social distancing and containment measures. To prevent community spread after the first case was diagnosed on 
23 February 2020, a nation-wide lockdown was introduced in late March 2020, followed by imposition of preventive

social distancing and containment measures. On 6 June 2020, the nationwide lockdown was extended for three more 
months until early August, with new health guidelines, (i) requiring face masks in public places at all times and older 
people staying home; (ii) introducing restrictions on public transport and screening at ports of entry; (iii) closing all 
educational centers and public places for gathering; (iv) disinfecting workplaces; and (v) reducing business hours for 
government and nongovernmental organizations. MOPH in coordination with Kabul Municipality has disinfected 
residential buildings, roads, and government offices (including ministries, jails, and hospitals) and provided guidelines 
on disinfection. On 26 March 2020, over 12,000 prisoners were released and directed to stay in home quarantine for 
14 days with a presidential decree as part of the COVID-19 prevention measures. Since mid-July, border crossings 
and domestic and international flights have resumed. Public schools (11th and 12th Grades) and both public and 
private universities have reopened on 22 August 2020. The 1st – 10th grades of the public schools have been 
reopened since 3 October 2020. However, the private schools (1st – 12th Grade) have been conditionally opened 
since 22 August 2020 if they provide the minimum health measures such as masks, social distancing, etc.  
 
Institutional framework of health sector measures. The MOPH approved the NERP for COVID-19 in March 2020 
and developed an action plan for the preventive measures. A new structure within MOPH was created to implement 
the NERP and the action plan. The NERP details the medium and long-term strategy for a robust national health 
security agenda for all hazards and pandemic preparedness, as well as the resource requirements and development 
coordination for (i) surveillance and detection; (ii) early diagnosis, isolation, and case management; (iii) infection 
prevention and control in health facilities and communities; (iv) risk mitigation; and (v) resource allocation for logistics 
and procurement for emergency responses based on the COVID-19 preparedness and response plans of the WHO 
and the UNICEF. Based on NERP, the estimated health sector resource requirement for the pandemic response 
(using three scenarios of low to high transmission) ranges between $123 million to $892 million.  
 
In April 2020, provincial emergency committees for COVID-19 were formed in all 34 provinces, comprising governors, 
provincial councils, provincial health administrations, municipalities, and civil society in collaboration with WHO and 
relevant UN agencies for surveillance, health care services, and risk communication. The local governments play a 
critical role in implementation of national containment measures as well as provision of vital services and social 
protection support. 
 
Implementation of health sector measures. Based on the national action plan, the MOPH has been strengthening 
the capacity of medical facilities with strong gender focus such as establishment of women-only treatment areas at 
identified medical facilities and provision of appropriately sized personal protective gears, including individual 
packages for female health workers. Nearly 570,000 units of personal protective equipment were provided to health 
workers nationwide as of 12 November 2020 with support from development partners such as WHO, World Bank, 
UNICEF and bilateral donors. Furthermore, 8 hospitals have been designated for exclusive use by the COVID-19 
patients; around 3,100 beds in 34 provinces have been assigned to COVID-19 patients, from which 1,030 are for 
critical patients. Medical equipment has been provided for 1,642 isolation beds across all 34 provinces. A new 100-
bed COVID-19 hospital has been opened in Herat province. In Kabul, the Darulaman Palace (300 beds) as well as 
Kabul and Polytechnic universities’ dormitories have been converted to isolation facilities. MOPH has been preparing

10 additional 50-bed medical facilities in Herat, Farrah, Neemruz and Kabul. Development partners, including ADB 
have been providing support to MOPH to rehabilitate and expand new treatment facilities including prefabricated ones. 
 
A total of 14 COVID-19 testing labs across the country with 5 labs in Kabul were established, equipped with 500 
ventilators purchased through the National Procurement Authority, polymerase chain reaction machines and testing 
kits. As of 12 November 2020, 4,350 healthcare workers received training on infection prevention and control, 3,931 
healthcare workers on surveillance and risk communication, 444 healthcare workers on intensive care and 193 
healthcare workers on medical laboratory testing. With the private hospitals also allowed to conduct tests, Afghanistan 
has reached the capacity to carry out 5,500 tests per day and as of 19 November 2020, 133,691 tests were conducted.  
 
To strengthen surveillance and early detection, in addition to 525 MOPH sites, COVID-19 surveillance sites in airports, 
borders, and city entrance points have been established and mobile teams have been trained. As of 12 November 
2020, 519,023 people have been medically screened at points-of-entry and the surveillance systems have traced 
591,232 people since the start of the crisis in March 2020. Nearly 4,000 governmental and nongovernmental units 
operate  across  the  country  to  gather  information  daily  and  share  with  the  national  and  international  health 
organizations. MOPH has recruited and trained more than 6,000 medical staff with additional 3,000 medical staff 
planned to be hired. Medical staff has been provided salaries with incentive payments. 
 
A nationwide gender-sensitive public awareness campaign on COVID-19 has been carried out by the MOPH and 
Ministry of Women Affairs. Using mosques, educational institutions as well as national print and broadcasting media, 
social media, billboards, cell phone messages, around 10 million pieces of COVID-19 related informational documents 
have been distributed. Nearly 3 million people have been sensitized about hygiene promotion through handwashing 
stations and distribution of hygiene kits. Ministry of Women Affairs has been involved in 117 districts in 26 provinces 
by (i) visiting women jails, safe homes, shelters, businesses headed by women, orphanages, private banks, hospitals 
and clinics to distribute gender-sensitive information and sanitary kits, (ii) monitoring adherence to safety measures, 
and (iii) facilitating gender-sensitive services for women, particularly in hospitals with all women-only treatment 
facilities. Health kits for street children have been distributed. A call center was set up at MOPH.  
 
Development partner support. The government has also received support from the WHO, United Nations agencies, 
and development partners for procurement of medical equipment and supplies, expansion of health sector capacity 
with new facilities, capacity building on pandemic management and provision of health services for the vulnerable 
communities such as IDPs, refugees, women and children during the pandemic. Besides the health sector measures, 
the  government’s response includes  expansion of  social protection for  the  poor  and vulnerable people, and 
macroeconomic stabilization measures with further details provided under criteria 2.  
 
5. Debt Sustainability  Afghanistan has become eligible for DSSI, endorsed in April 2020 by the World Bank’s Development Committee and 
the G20 finance ministers in response to a call by the World Bank and the IMF to grant debt service suspension to the 
poorest countries. In return, beneficiaries of DSSI commit to use freed-up resources to increase social, health, or 
economic spending in response to the pandemic while disclosing all public sector financial commitments (involving

Appendix 4  35 
Access Criteria  Asian Development Bank Assessment 
debt and debt-like instruments) and limiting their non-concessional borrowing as supported by ceilings under the IMF 
programs and the World Bank’s non-concessional borrowing policies. Around $4 million of interest and principal 
payments to bilateral creditors during May−December 2020 will be paid starting 2022. Afghanistan’s potential DSSI 
savings are $39.1 million (0.2% of 2019 GDP) based on estimated debt service payments. Furthermore, the IMF has 
provided debt service relief of SDR4.8 million ($6.8 million) under two tranches in April 2020 and October 2020 with 
a total relief of SDR10.05 million ($14.4 million) by 2022 under the Catastrophe Containment and Relief Trust. 
 
During the pandemic, the IMF provided a concessional loan of SDR161.9 million ($220 million) under the Rapid Credit 
Facility, approved on 29 April 2020. An additional concessional IMF loan of SDR259.04 million ($370 million) under 
the ECF arrangement was approved on 6 November 2020. These budget support loans represent 49% of outstanding 
public debt stock of $1.2 billion. In 2020, Afghanistan also received infrastructure project loans of $208 million from 
some development partners adding another 17% to the public debt stock. Based on ADB’s DSA, which simulated 
scenarios on drivers of debt dynamics such as growth, exchange rate, real interest rate, and primary deficit, these 
loans will increase the public debt−GDP ratio from 6.3% in 2019 to 10.7% in 2020 and 16.6% of GDP in 2021, however 
the ratio is projected to decline to 13.4% in 2024. These loans will not significantly increase the annual debt service 
obligations and debt sustainability as the public debt will stay moderately low. ADB’s $100 million grant under the 
CARES Program will help create fiscal space and improve debt sustainability during the pandemic.  
 
Afghanistan’s public debt sustainability hinges on continuing net inflows of highly concessional development finance 
over the medium and long term. Liabilities consist mostly of concessional and project-based loans from multilateral 
and bilateral creditors. This keeps borrowing costs low and limits rollover and interest-rate risks, although the foreign-
currency denomination of public external debt constitutes currency risk.  
 
Nevertheless, the IMF’s pre-shock DSA under Article IV consultation report in 2019 and its DSA after the pandemic 
in Rapid Credit Facility report in April 2020 and in ECF report in November 2020 as well as ADB’s recent DSA rate 
Afghanistan at high risk of debt distress mainly because of an expected decline of grants financing fiscal and external 
deficits in the medium and long term. Key factors for the high risk of debt distress are (i) high dependence on donor 
grant inflows, which finance substantial fiscal and external deficits, (ii) the expected replacement of grants by debt 
financing over time, which will increase the debt service burden given the weak debt carrying and low revenue 
generation capacities, (iii) export shocks, and (iv) the fragile political and security situation.  
 
To facilitate transitioning of the low-income countries (including Afghanistan) to non-concessional borrowing, the IMF 
and World Bank have approved the SDFP in effect from 1 July 2020 to strengthen public debt management framework. 
This is aligned with the IMF and the World Bank support for the implementation of the DSSI—by monitoring spending, 
enhancing public debt transparency, and ensuring prudent borrowing. ADB will continue to support debt sustainability 
during the Asian Development Fund 13 period (2021−2024) through additional TA for its developing member countries 
for the implementation the SDFP.
